hints.content:
We can always switch the $\goldD{\text{bounds}}$ of the integral. This also switches the sign of the integral:

$\displaystyle \int_{\goldD0}^\goldD{-4} \blueD{g(x)} \, dx = \goldD-\displaystyle \int_{\goldD{-4}}^\goldD0 \blueD{g(x)} \, dx$

Now we can focus on $\displaystyle \int_{-4}^0 \blueD{g(x)} \, dx$ and worry about the negative in front later.

$\displaystyle \int_{-4}^0 \blueD{g(x)} \, dx$ is the net area between $\blueD{g(x)}$ and the $x$-axis from $x = -4$ to $x = 0$.

![Function g is graphed. The x-axis goes from negative 8 to 5. The graph consists of a smooth curve. The curve starts at (negative 4, 0), moves downward to a relative minimum in quadrant 3, moves upward and ends at (0, 0). The region above the curve and below the x-axis between x-intercepts negative 4 and 0 has area negative 6.](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ae5c4cc642c9706fbe2a6d7c16d196e1cbfa61f9)

From the graph:

$\displaystyle \int_{-4}^0 \blueD{g(x)} \, dx=\maroonE{-6}$

Now all we have to do is apply the negative to the integral:

$\begin{align}&\phantom{=}-\displaystyle \int_{-4}^0 \blueD{g(x)} \, dx
\\\\
& = -(\maroonE{-6})
\\\\
&=6
\end{align}$

answers.message: Don't forget to reverse the bounds of the integral. This switches the sign of the integral.
